div.p:
I have [now] the honor to […] to acknowledge the receipt or your valued letters bearing the date 26 February containing the welcome information of your intention to send forwards several species of Russian animals for the Acclimatisation Society of Victoria.
According to a report of the meeting of the Council of the Acclimatisation Society of Victoria held on 17 May 1864 (Argus, 19 May 1864, p. 5), the Moscow Acclimatisation Society had promised to send to Melbourne, in exchange for animals that had been sent to them, 'a pair of Romanovsky sheep, a pair of Kalmuck sheep, a pair of Russian sheep-dogs, and several species of Russian poultry and waterfowl'. In conveying to you the thanks of the Council of the said Society may I request that all letters bearing upon the interests of the Society may be addressed either to the President (E. Wilson Esq) or to myself as Secretary as our worthy Vice President Dr Mueller has such a voluminous correspondence that the Council are desirous of [reducing] [his/him] as far as possible[.] I trust my letter of March 25. reached you safely and we hope also to hear of the safe arrival of the birds therein advised.
